Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Work, Family, and Social Well-Being among Couples in the Context of COVID-19

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: COVID-19 has disrupted daily work and home lives. More than 297 million people in the U.S. have been placed on full or partial social distancing restrictions. Millions were told to work remotely; others were deemed essential and found themselves on the frontline of this unprecedented pandemic. More than half the schools are closed, leaving more than 33 million children at home. Consequently, millions of dual-income families have been forced to find new ways to balance the competing needs of work and family while maintaining individual and relational well-being. Prior to COVID-19, research consistently showed workers to experience higher work-to-family than family-to-work conflict; however, workers may now experience as high, if not higher, family-to-work conflict given that they have to juggle work and family from the same location: home. Both of these conflicts can have negative effects on individuals and families, including psychological distress, anxiety, anger, guilt, and decreased couple relationship quality. Most studies to date have tested spillover effects of work to family conflict using individual-level data; few have examined the crossover effect with both members included in the analysis, and even fewer longitudinally. This project will survey and interview both adults of dual-income couples at three time points to assess how work, family, and health among dual-income couples have changed within the context of COVID-19. Findings from this project will inform workplaces on the development of policies to support workers and their families during times of crisis and return-to-work transitions, thus facilitating recovery from this pandemic and preparedness for future extreme events. These are key insights needed to train employers/workers on best practices for employment interventions on family-friendly policies, facilitating organizational change and contributing to healthy workplaces, thus facilitating health and well-being and U. S. economic competitiveness.<br/><br/><br/>Covid-19 has disrupted work and family arrangements owing to school closures, requirements for telework, and social distancing mandates. This project uses a mixed-methods approach by combining surveys and in-depth interviews with both members of a sample of dual-income couples over one year. The project will collect data at three time points: baseline (while most of country is under lockdown orders), transition (after orders start to phase out), and adaptation (one year after the first case of community transmission was detected). The project will use both a traditional single person data analysis strategy, including growth curve modeling and panel regression, and a dyadic data analytical method, the Actor-Partner Interdependence Model, to analyze survey data (n=300 couples; 600 individuals). For the qualitative data, the project will use a thematic analysis to identify emergent patterns on perceptual/behavioral work-family conflict, workplace resources/support, mental health, and relationships. The project will use the qualitative software package NVIVO to manage interview data. Findings from the project will inform sociological theories regarding work-family conflict and accommodation, as well as theories related to the gendered division of household labor.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
COVID-19 has created unprecedented disruptions to home and work lives. This study uses a mixed-methods approach to assess work, family, and social well-being among heterosexual, dual-earning couples in the U.S. over time, within the context of COVID-19. Our sample includes couples with at least one child 17 years or younger living at home (73%) and childfree couples (27%). We collected three waves of survey data with both members of the couple: baseline (n=430 couples; most were under lockdown orders), transition (n=165 couples; after orders began to lift), and adaptation (n=116 couples; 18 months after lockdowns began). We interviewed a subset of couples (n=38) after baseline and adaptation surveys. The dyadic study design allows us to evaluate work, family, and social well-being of the individual and how experiences of one partner cross over to the other partner. Couple-level data are important because partners do not always have sufficient information about the other's lived experiences (e.g., work-family conflict), which leads to "assumed similarity bias," where one may assume another's lived experience is similar to one's own experience. We use individual (e.g., growth curve modeling; panel regression) and dyadic data analytical methods (i.e., the Actor-Partner Interdependence Model; Cook & Kenny 2005; Kenny et al. 2006) to analyze survey data. For the qualitative data, we use a thematic analysis to identify patterns on core outcomes: work-family conflict, workplace resources/support, mental health, and relationships.

The study offers insights into work, family, and social well-being. First, given distinct work configurations during COVID-19, we use a novel scale to measure how the extent of remote work impacts behavioral work-family conflict outcomes (Clark et al. 2019) for each member of a couple and how this crosses over to affect their partner's work-family conflict. We find couples experience higher family-to-work conflict than work-to-family conflict, opposite of most prior research. However, experiences are distinct. Mother's family-to-work conflict and work-to-family conflict increases the more they work remotely but also the more their partner works remotely. In contrast, for non-parents, work-to-family conflict decreases for women and men the more they work remotely. However, the positive impact of one's own remote work on work-to family and family-to work conflict is tempered if their partner also works at home, particularly stronger for women. Our qualitative data supports survey findings; while all parents experience higher family-to-work conflict, the complexity of mothers' narratives reveal work-family struggles, particularly those with flexible schedules; fathers report fewer impacts to their work/home lives.

Second, despite some expectation the gap between women's and men's contribution to housework/caregiving tasks might narrow, our data shows this is not the case. Women assume at least 60% of household physical and mental labor, and significantly so if they both had worked outside the home during the pandemic. Furthermore, 50% or more of couples disagree on who performs about half the physical housework items and almost all the mental labor. For caregiving, couples agree on slightly more items. When couples do not agree, the male partner says they do more of the share of housework/mental labor than credited by their female partner. By including both members of a couple to assess agreement between couples on "who does what," we disentangle biases in self-ratings. Interviews with couples show that women experience a higher burden of housework/caregiving tasks independent of work location; their male partner largely agrees.

Third, results highlight social well-being outcomes. Analyses suggest the mental health of parents of minor children, measured by psychological distress, is impacted more negatively by the onset of COVID-19 and daily life restrictions. Additionally, the pandemic influences how couples employ individual, social, and communal coping strategies to manage distress. Interview data finds couples use three metaphors to explain coping: conflict highlighting incompatibility, fiction highlighting sur-reality/uncertainty, and control highlighting feelings of little influence over their situation.

Findings offer broader impacts. Findings may inform workplaces on policy development to support workers and their families as they implement return-to-work transitions (e.g., flextime/place; supervisor/organizational support), facilitating pandemic recovery and preparedness for future extreme events. However, given gendered and parental status findings, a "one-size-fits all" approach is unlikely to be effective. These are key insights to train employers/workers on best practices for employment interventions on family-friendly policies, fostering organizational change, contributing to healthy workplaces, and supporting U.S. economic competitiveness.

Another broader impact is that COVID-19 may have uncovered mental health differences among different groups. The negative impact of the lack of childcare and flexibility, for example, on mental health, evident prior to the pandemic, may have increased during the pandemic. The results of our study call on policy makers and employers to provide working adults the formal (e.g., affordable/reliable family caregiving supports) and informal work-life supports (e.g., discouraging 24/7 connectivity to work through electronic communications) necessary to improve mental health outcomes of both employees and their family.
